data.title: 27 bands and musicians you forgot (or didn't know) were from Pennsylvania
data.meta_description: Take a look at 27 of the biggest names in music that call Pennsylvania home, from hip-hop to pop and jazz to big band. You can see a few of them at the Grammy Awards tonight!
data.text:
When you think of Pennsylvania, you might not automatically think of music superstardom. But our state has more than its fair share of acclaimed and popular performers, ranging in genres from hip-hop to big band. A few of them are even nominated for Grammy Awards, and can be found at tonight's ceremony.

Take a look at 27 of the biggest names in music that call Pennsylvania home!

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Hall & Oates

Daryl Hall and John Oates both are Philly natives, and their meeting would lead to six number one hits on the Billboard 100 list.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Todd Rundgren

Long before Adele sang "Hello, it's me," Todd Rundgren was born in the Philadelphia area. His album "Something/Anything" made the Rolling Stone list of the 500 greatest albums of all time.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Chris Kirkpatrick of 'NSync

Kirkpatrick nearly made the cut for the Backstreet Boys, but the Clarion, Pa. native went on to team up with Timberlake and company instead.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Frankie Avalon

Forget 'NSync for 'nsecond, though, because one of the original teen heartthrob singers, Frankie Avalon, was originally from Philadelphia. Guess all those beach movies took place in Jersey?

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Chubby Checker

Though Ernest Evans was born in South Carolina, he was raised in South Philly and earned the nickname Chubby Checker while performing impressions of other singers, including Fats Domino, around the neighborhood.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Jim Croce

Croce hailed from South Philadelphia, and one of his early jobs as a musician was a regular gig at a steakhouse in Lima, Pa.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

The Dorsey Brothers

Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey were both born around Shenandoah, Pa. The brothers were successful both together and as solo acts in the jazz and big band era.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Eve

Eve Jihan Jeffers-Cooper began performing as part of a singing group in a Philadelphia high school talent show. "Attitude rude? That's the Philly in I / Need me in the game, I'm the thrill in your life" indeed.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Perry Como

Perry Como once had the ambition to become the best barber in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania. He went on to become one of the most famous crooners ever, which is almost as good.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Beanie Sigel and Freeway

Both Beanie Sigel (whose stage name is taken from Sigel Street in Philly) and Freeway came up from the Philadelphia rap scene, and caught the attention of Roc-A-Fella Records mogul Jay Z.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

DJ Jazzy Jeff and the Fresh Prince

Of course we all remember that Will Smith is from West Philadelphia, born and raised. But still, sometimes it's easy to forget that he was a radio-friendly rapper along with fellow Philly native DJ Jazzy Jeff.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

.+

While both Ed Kowalczyk now tours and performs separately from the rest of the group, he and bassist Patrick Dahlheimer and drummer Chad Gracey all originally hail from York.

MORE: 'Lightning Crashes' turns 20: Live's Ed Kowalczyk, Chad Gracey share memories of York band's hit

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Patti LaBelle

The Godmother of Soul hails from Philadelphia, and before hitting it big as a solo act, was also the lead singer in Patti LaBelle and the Bluebelles.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Poison

With Brett Michaels from Butler and Bobby Dall and Rikki Rockett from Mechanicsburg, Poison may be one of the most Pennsylvania rock bands out there. Take that as you will.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Wiz Khalifa

If Wiz Khalifa's anthem to the colors of the Steelers wasn't enough to tip you off, we can confirm the rapper is from Pittsburgh.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Pink and Christina Aguilera

Both Pink (from Doylestown) and Aguilera (who was raised outside of Pittsburgh) probably deserve their own slide. But since they are together in this cover of a Patti LaBelle song, it seemed a mistake to enjoy the Keystone State reunion.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Taylor Swift

Tay-Tay has long had that girl-next-door vibe, but to a few residents of Reading, Wyomissing and other small Pennsylvania towns, she was quite literally just that.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Nine Inch Nails

Speaking of segues, here's a song by Nine Inch Nails. Trent Reznor was born in New Castle and grew up in Mercer. Aside from shared Pennsylvania roots, I wonder if he and Taylor Swift have literally anything else in common.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

The Roots

And when it comes to Pennsylvania roots, you've got two great choices for bands. ?uestlove and Black Thought started out in Philly and now serve as Jimmy Fallon's late-night house band.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Rusted Root

From the other side of the state, there's Pittsburgh-based Rusted Root. Is there any song that has been featured in more commercials than "Send Me On My Way"?

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Henry Mancini

You might not recognize Mancini's name right away, but you're almost sure to recognize his music - he did the score for numerous films, including many directed by Blake Edwards. Mancini was born in Ohio but raised outside of Pittsburgh.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Joan Jett

Whether she was performing with The Runaways or The Blackhearts, it's clear that Joan Jett loves rock and roll. She was raised in Wynnewood, outside of Philadelphia.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Boyz II Men

If you couldn't guess from the title and content of one of their biggest hits, the R&B group Boyz II Men is actually from the City of Brotherly Love.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Train

While the group Train formed in San Fransisco, lead singer Patrick Monahan is from Erie, Pennsylvania.

MORE: Train's lead singer Pat Monahan on Hershey memories, going mainstream and trying to recreate 'Drops of Jupiter'

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

The Bloodhound Gang

If you only think of King of Prussia because of the awesome mall, you can also add "hometown of The Bloodhound Gang" to its list of accomplishments. (Has anyone done a mash-up with this and "Closer"? Let's look into that, people.)

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Billie Holiday

Lady Day was born in Philadelphia, and while faced struggles with drugs and abuse, she was one of the most groundbreaking jazz singers of her era.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Breaking Benjamin

Benjamin Burnley was raised in Selinsgrove and moved to Wilkes-Barre, where he and Jeremy Hummel founded Breaking Benjamin.

Breaking Benjamin earns first number one album on Billboard 200 charts

In this Aug. 16, 2015, file photo, Wiz Khalifa accepts the choice R&B/hip-hop song award for "See You Again" at the Teen Choice Awards at the Galen Center in Los Angeles. Pittsburgh police say rapper Wiz Khalifa has been cited for urinating in public.

Sean Adams | sadams@pennlive.com

Who did we miss?

Who's your favorite on our list of homegrown music heroes? Did we leave out any major players in the music biz from our neck of the woods? Share them with us in the comments!
